editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).

div.p: AN ORATION DELIVERED APRIL EIGHTH, 1776.

AN ORATION; DELIVERED AT THE King's-CHAPEL IN BOSTON, APRIL 8, 1776, On the Re-Interment of the Remains of the late MOST WORSHIPFUL GRAND-MASTER JOSEPH WARREN, ESQUIRE; PRESIDENT of the late CONGRESS of this Colony, AND MAJOR-GENERAL of the MASSACHUSETTS FORCES; Who was Slain in the Battle of BUNKER's-HILL, JUNE 17, 1775.
BY PEREZ MORTON, M. M.
BOSTON: PRINTED, AND TO BE SOLD BY J. GILL, IN QUEEN-STREET. 1776.

I AM reque≈øted by the Brethren of the Grand Lodge, to beg the favor of you to pronounce an ORATION on Monday next, at the re-interment of our late Grand Ma≈øter JOSEPH WARREN, E≈øq which I doubt not you will perform with credit to your≈øelf and ≈øatisfaction to your audience.

closer.signed: I am, your affectionate brother, and humble ≈øervant, JOSEPH WEBB, D. G. M.

div.p: BROTHER MORTON pre≈øents his re≈øpects to Brother WEBB, and the other Officers of the Grand Lodge, and thanks them for the honor done him in their reque≈øting him to pronounce an ORATION on the re-interment of the late Grand Ma≈øter; and gives for an≈øwer, that he will endeavor to prepare him≈øelf, and has no other apology to urge for any deficiencies, that may appear, than his want of abilities for ≈øo important an undertaking, and the ≈øhortne≈øs of time given him to prepare in.
div.trailer: To the Right Wor≈øhipful JOSEPH WEBB. D. G. Ma≈øter, BOSTON.

div.p: AT a Meeting of the Grand Lodge, and a numerous body of Free and Accepted Ma≈øons, after the re-interment of our Mo≈øt Wor≈øhipful Grand Ma≈øter, JOSEPH WARREN, E≈øq who was ≈ølain in the battle of Bunker's-Hill, June 17, 1775.
In the Chair, the Right Wor≈øhipful JOSEPH WEBB, D. G. M.

VOTED, That our Brothers Paul Revere, Edward Proctor, and Stephen Bruce, be a committee to wait on our brother Perez Morton, E≈øq and pre≈øent our mo≈øt cordial thanks, for his ORATION delivered this afternoon, and reque≈øt a copy thereof for the pre≈øs.

FROM that duty, which I owe to the Lodge, I am con≈øtrained to comply with your reque≈øt; and ≈øhall urge no other apology for the defects of the performance, than the very ≈øhort time that was given me to prepare it in, added to my mo≈øt ≈øincere wi≈øhes of having been better able to have done ju≈øtice to the exalted character of the ≈øubject of it.

closer.signed: I am, with due re≈øpect, your mo≈øt affectionate brother, PEREZ MORTON.

div.head: AN ORATION.
div.p:
WHAT Tidings from the Grave! Why ha≈øt thou left the peaceful Man≈øions of the Tomb, to vi≈øit again this troubled Earth! Art thou the welcome Me≈ø≈øenger of Peace! Art thou ri≈øen again to exhibit thy glorious Wounds, and thro' them proclaim Salvation to thy Country! Or art thou come to demand that la≈øt Debt of Humanity, to which your Rank and Merit have ≈øo ju≈øtly entitled you‚Äîbut which has been ≈øo long ungenerou≈øly withheld! And art thou angry at the barbarous u≈øage? Be appea≈øed, ≈øweet Gho≈øt! For tho' thy Body has long laid undi≈øtingui≈øhed among the vulgar Dead, ≈øcarce priveleged
with Earth enough to hide it from the Birds of Prey; tho' not a kindred Tear was dropt, tho' not a friendly Sigh was uttered, o'er thy Grave; and tho' the Execrations of an impious Foe, were all thy Funeral Knells; yet matchle≈øs Patriot! thy Memory has been embalmed in the Affections of thy grateful Countrymen; who in their Brea≈øt have rai≈øed eternal Monuments to thy Bravery!

BUT let us leave the beloved Remains, and contemplate for a Moment, tho≈øe Virtues of the Man, the Exerci≈øe of which have ≈øo de≈øervedly endeared him to the hone≈øt among the Great, and the Good among the humble.

IN the private Walks of Life, he was a Pattern for Mankind.‚ÄîThe Tears of her, to whom the World's indebted for ≈øo much Virtue, are ≈øilent Heralds of his filial Piety: While his tender Offspring, in li≈øping out their Father's Care, proclaim his parential Affection: And an ADAMS can witne≈øs with how much Zeal he loved, where he had formed the ≈øacred Connection of a Friend;‚Äî their kindred Souls were ≈øo clo≈øely twined, that both felt one Joy, both one Affliction. In Conver≈øation he had the happy Talent of addre≈ø≈øing his Subject both to the Under≈øtanding and the Pa≈ø≈øions; from the one he forced Conviction, from the other he ≈øtole A≈ø≈øent.

HE was ble≈ø≈øed with a Complacency of Di≈øpo≈øition, and Equanimity of Temper, which peculiarly endeared him to his Friends;
and which, added to the Deportment of the Gentleman, commanded Reverence and E≈øteem even from his Enemies.

SUCH was the tender Sen≈øibility of his Soul, that he need but ≈øee Di≈øtre≈øs to feel it, and contribute to its Relief.‚ÄîHe was deaf to the Calls of Intere≈øt even in the Cour≈øe of his Profe≈ø≈øion; and wherever he beheld an indigent Object, which claimed his healing Skill, he admini≈øtred it, without even the Hope of any other Reward, than that which re≈øulted from the Reflection of having ≈øo far promoted the Happine≈øs of his Fellow Men.

IN the ≈øocial Departments of Life, practi≈øing upon the Strength of that Doctrine, he u≈øed ≈øo earne≈øtly to inculcate him≈øelf, that nothing ≈øo much conduced to enlighten Mankind, and advance the great End of Society at large, as the frequent Interchange of Sentiments, in friendly Meetings; we find him con≈øtantly engaged in this eligible Labour; but on none did he place ≈øo high a Value, as on that mo≈øt honorable of all detached Societies, THE FREE AND ACCEPTED MASONS: Into this Fraternity he was early initiated; and after having given repeated Proofs of a rapid Proficiency in the Arts, and after evidencing by his Life, the Profe≈ø≈øions of his Lips‚Äî finally, as the Reward of his Merit, he was commi≈ø≈øioned the mo≈øt wor≈øhipful GRAND MASTER of all the ancient Ma≈øons, thro' North-America.‚ÄîAnd you, Brethren, are living Te≈øtimonies, with how much Honor to him≈øelf, and Benefit to the Craft univer≈øal, he di≈øcharged the Duties of his elevated Tru≈øt; with what ≈øweetned
Accents he courted your Attention, while with Wi≈ødom, Strength and Beauty, he in≈øtructed his Lodges in the ≈øecret Arts of Free-ma≈øonry; what perfect Order and Decorum he pre≈øerved in the Government of them; and in all his Conduct, what a bright Example he ≈øet us, to live within Compa≈øs, and act upon the Square.

WITH what Plea≈øure did he ≈øilence the Wants of poor and pennyle≈øs Brethren; yea the Nece≈ø≈øitous every where, tho' ignorant of the My≈øteries of the Craft, from his Benefactions, felt the happy Effects of that In≈øtitution which is founded on Faith, Hope and Charity. And the World may cea≈øe to wonder, that he ≈øo readily offered up his Life, on the Altar of his Country, when they are told, that the main Pillar of Ma≈øonry, is the LOVE OF MANKIND.

THE Fates, as tho' they would reveal, in the Per≈øon of our GRAND MASTER, tho≈øe My≈øteries, which have ≈øo long lain hid from the World, have ≈øuffered him, like the great Ma≈øter-builder in the Temple of old, to fall by the Hands of Ruffians, and be again rai≈øed in Honor and Authority: We ≈øearched in the Field for the murdered Son of a Widow, and we found him, by the Turf and the Twig, buried on the Brow of a Hill, tho' not in a decent Grave.‚ÄîAnd tho' we mu≈øt again commit his Body to the Tomb, yet our Brea≈øts ≈øhall be the Burying Spot of his Ma≈øonic Virtues, and there‚Äî

IN public Life, the ≈øole Object of his Ambition was to acquire the Con≈øcience of virtuous Enterprizes; Amor Patriae was the Spring of his Actions, and Mens Con≈øcia Recti was his Guide.‚Äî And on this Security he was, on every Occa≈øion, ready to ≈øacrifice his Health, his Intere≈øt and his Ea≈øe, to the ≈øacred Calls of his Country. When the Liberties of America were attacked, he appeared an early Champion in the Conte≈øt; and tho' his Knowledge and Abilities would have in≈øured Riches and Preferment (could he have ≈øtoop'd to Pro≈øtitution) yet he nobly with≈øtood the fa≈øcinating Charm, to≈ø≈øed Fortune back her Plume, and per≈øued the inflexible Purpo≈øe of his Soul, in guiltle≈øs Competence.

HE ≈øought not the airy Honors of a Name, el≈øe, many of tho≈øe Publications, which in the early Period of our Controver≈øy ≈øerved to open the Minds of the People, had not appeared anonymous. In every time of eminent Danger, his Fellow-Citizens flew to him for Advice; like the Orator of Athens, he gave it, and di≈øpell'd their Fears:‚ÄîTwice did they call him to the Ro≈øtrum, to commemorate the Ma≈ø≈øacre of their Brethren; and from that In≈øtance, in per≈øua≈øive Language he taught them, not only the dangerous Tendency, but the actual Mi≈øchief, of ≈øtationing a Military Force, in a free City, in a Time of Peace.‚ÄîThey learnt the profitable Le≈ø≈øon, and pen'd it among their Grievances.

BUT his Abilities were too great, his Deliberations too much wanted, to be confined to the Limits of a ≈øingle City, and at a Time when our Liberties were mo≈øt critically in Danger from the ≈øecret Machinations and open A≈ø≈øaults of our Enemies, this Town, to their la≈øting Honor, elected him to take a Part in the Councils of the State.‚ÄîAnd with what Faithfulne≈øs he di≈øcharged the important Delegation, the Neglect of his private Concerns, and his unwearied Attendance on that Betru≈øtment, will ≈øufficiently te≈øtify: and the Records of that virtuous A≈ø≈øembly will remain the Te≈øtimonials of his Accompli≈øhments as a State≈øman, and his Integrity and Services as a Patriot, thro' all Po≈øterity.

The Congre≈øs of our Colony could not ob≈øerve ≈øo much Virtue and Greatne≈øs without honoring it with the highe≈øt Mark of their Favour; and by the free Suffrages of that uncorrupted Body of Freemen, he was ≈øoon called to pre≈øide in the Senate.‚ÄîWhere by his daily Councils and Exertions, he was con≈øtantly promoting the great Cau≈øe of General Liberty.

BUT when he found the Tools of Oppre≈ø≈øion were ob≈øtinately bent on Violence; when he found the Vengeance of the Briti≈øh Court mu≈øt he glutted with Blood; he determined, that what he could not effect by his Eloquence or his Pen, he would bring to Purpo≈øe by his Sword. And on the memorable 19th of April, he appeared in the Field, under the united Characters of the General, the Soldier and the Phy≈øician.‚ÄîHere he was ≈øeen animating his
Countrymen to Battle, and fighting by their Side, and there he was found admini≈øtering healing Comforts to the wounded. And when he had repelled the unprovoked A≈ø≈øaults of the Enemy, and had driven them back into their Strong-holds, like the virtuous Chief of Rome, he returned to the Senate, and pre≈øided again at the Councils of the Fathers.

WHEN the vanqui≈øhed Foe had rallied their di≈øordered Army, and by the Acqui≈øition of fre≈øh Strength, again pre≈øumed to fight again≈øt Freemen; our Patriot, ever anxious to be, where he could do the mo≈øt good, again put off the Senator, and in Contempt of Danger flew to the Field of Battle, where, after a ≈øtern, and almo≈øt victorious Re≈øi≈øtance, ah! too ≈øoon for his Country! he ≈øealed his Principles with his Blood‚Äîthen‚Äî
div.l: But WARREN's Manes "mu≈øt enrich the Grave."
div.p: Enriched indeed! And the Heights of Charle≈øtown ≈øhall be more memorable for thy Fall, than the Plains of Abraham are for that of the Hero of Britain. For while he died contending for a ≈øingle Country, You fell in the Cau≈øe of Virtue and Mankind.

THE Greatne≈øs of his Soul ≈øhone even in the Moment of Death; for if Fame ≈øpeaks true, in his la≈øt Agonies he met the In≈øults of his barbarous Foe, with his wonted Magnanimity, and with the true Spirit of a Soldier, frowned at their Impotence.
IN Fine, to compleat the great Character‚Äîlike HARRINGTON he wrote, like CICERO he ≈øpoke, like HAMPDEN he lived, and like WOLFE he died.

AND can we, my Countrymen, with Indifference behold ≈øo much Worth and Valour laid pro≈øtrate by the Hand of Briti≈øh Tyranny! And can we ever gra≈øp that Hand in Affection again? ‚ÄîAre we not yet convinced "that he who hunts the Woods for Prey, the naked and untutored Indian, is le≈øs a Savage than the King of Britain"! Have we not Proofs, wrote in Blood, that the corrupted Nation, from whence we ≈øprang (tho' there may be ≈øome Traces of their ancient Virtue left) are ≈øtubbornly fixed on our De≈øtruction! And ≈øhall we ≈øtill court a Dependance on ≈øuch a State? Still contend for a Connection with tho≈øe, who have forfeited not only every kindred Claim, but even their Title to Humanity! Forbid it the Spirit of the brave MONTGOMORY! Forbid it the Spirit of immortal WARREN! Forbid it the Spirits of all our valiant Countrymen! Who fought, bled and died for far different Purpo≈øes; and who would have thought the Purcha≈øe dear indeed! to have paid their Lives for the paltry Boon, of di≈øplacing one Set of Villains in Power, to make Way for another. No. They contended for the E≈øtabli≈øhment of Peace, Liberty and Safety to their Country, and we are unworthy to be called their Countrymen, if we ≈øtop at any Acpui≈øition ≈øhort of this.

Now is the happy Sea≈øon, to ≈øeize again tho≈øe Rights, which as Men we are by Nature entitled to, and which by Contract we never have and never could have ≈øurrendered:‚ÄîBut which have been repeatedly and violently attacked by the King, Lords and Commons of Britain. Ought we not then to di≈øclaim forever the forfeited Affinity; and by a timely Amputation of that rotten Limb of the Empire, prevent the Mortification of the whole? Ought we not to li≈øten to the Voice of our ≈ølaughtered Brethren, who are now proclaiming aloud to their Country‚Äî
div.l: Go tell the King, and tell him from our Spirits,
That you and Britons can be Friends no more;
Tell him to you all Tyrants are the ≈øame:
Or if in Bonds, the never conquer'd Soul
Can feel a Pang, more keen than Slavery's ≈øelf,
'Tis where the Chains that cru≈øh you into Du≈øt,
Are forg'd by Hands, from which you hop'd for Freedom.
div.p: Yes, we ought and will‚ÄîWe will a≈ø≈øert the Blood of our murdered Hero again≈øt thy ho≈øtile Oppre≈ø≈øions, O ≈øhamele≈øs Britain! and when "thy Cloud-cap'd Towers, thy gorgeous Palaces" ≈øhall by the Teeth of Pride and Folly be levell'd with the Du≈øt‚Äîand when thy Glory ≈øhall have faded like the We≈øtern Sunbeam‚Äîthe Name and the Virtues of WARREN ≈øhall remain immortal.
